options.c: Mercury manometer, Water manometer, Alcohol manometer, Oil manometer

questions.explanation: The presentation lists the primary dry type measuring devices used in aircraft as the Bourdon tube, Diaphragm, Capsule, and Bellows[cite: 406, 407, 408, 409, 410]. Wet type manometers are generally restricted to ground testing[cite: 411].

questions.question: What are the two types of thermocouple hot junctions shown for CHT measurement?

options.a: Probe and Vane types
options.b: Gasket and Bayonet types
options.c: Slotted and Drilled types

questions.explanation: The material shows two common physical forms for the hot junction of a thermocouple used for applications like CHT: the gasket type (which fits under a spark plug) and the bayonet type (which inserts into a well)[cite: 730, 787, 808].

questions.question: A direct reading fuel gauge with a mechanical linkage and a pointer magnet is used to display quantity on a dial. How is the motion transferred from the tank to the dial?

options.a: Through an electrical wire.
options.b: Through a flexible drive shaft.
options.c: Through magnetic coupling, with no direct connection through the instrument case.

questions.explanation: The diagram for this type of gauge shows a float and mechanical linkage inside the tank that rotates a magnet. This magnet is on the other side of a sealed barrier from a 'pointer magnet' attached to the instrument needle. The magnets are coupled, so as the internal magnet rotates, the pointer magnet follows it, moving the needle without any physical penetration of the gauge housing[cite: 836, 837].

questions.question: In a vane-type fuel flow meter, what component provides the restoring force that opposes the force of the fuel on the measuring vane?

options.a: A damper vane
options.b: A hairspring
options.c: A relief valve

questions.explanation: In this instrument, fuel flow pushes against a measuring vane, causing it to rotate. This rotation is opposed by a calibrated hairspring. The vane comes to rest when the force from the fuel flow is balanced by the restoring force of the hairspring. The amount of rotation is therefore proportional to the flow rate[cite: 979].

questions.question: A proximity sensor works by detecting a change in its magnetic field. What material must the 'target' be made of for this to work?

options.a: Plastic
options.b: Steel or another ferrous metal
options.c: Rubber

questions.explanation: The proximity sensing system described measures the distance of a steel target to its sensitive surface[cite: 1153]. As a metal target is moved near the sensor, it changes the sensor's inductance, which is how the position is detected[cite: 1161].

questions.question: Which instrument from the WWI era measured the rate at which the aircraft was climbing or descending?

options.a: Altimeter
options.b: Airspeed Indicator
options.c: Climb/Descent Indicator (Variometer)

questions.explanation: The Climb/Descent Indicator, also known as a Variometer, was used in WWI aircraft to show if the aircraft was climbing or descending and at what rate[cite: 55]. An altimeter shows altitude [cite: 47], and an airspeed indicator shows speed through the air[cite: 48].

questions.question: Why must instrument cases be sealed in a pressurized aircraft?

options.a: To keep the instruments warm at high altitudes.
options.b: To withstand the pressure differential between the cabin and the outside atmosphere.
options.c: To make them waterproof in case of a water landing.

questions.explanation: In a pressurized aircraft, the internal cabin pressure is much higher than the atmospheric pressure at its flying altitude. Instrument cases must be sealed to withstand this external pressure difference to prevent case damage and measurement errors[cite: 160, 161, 172].

questions.question: Which display technology is based on a semiconductor diode that emits light when current flows through it?

options.a: Liquid-Crystal Display (LCD)
options.b: Light Emitting Diode (LED)
options.c: Head-Up Display (HUD)

questions.explanation: A Light Emitting Diode (LED) is a semiconductor device that produces light when an electric current is passed through it[cite: 217]. LCDs work by modulating light with liquid crystals [cite: 215], and HUDs are a projection system[cite: 213].
